comments.commentBody: No employer ought make a profit off labor who the government  must supplement, and that is exactly what your low skill employers do, make wealth for themselves, off your tax dollars.
Not paying overtime is illegal see a lawyer
So what is your point? It seems you are arguing that we should keep pay for low skill jobs low, in order to protect low pay for semi-skilled jobs.

The fast food workers want $15 an hour, but in many cities, a pharmacy tech only makes $16-$17.

Higher wages in a non skilled job, will result in shortages in the more skilled jobs.
Why work in a job where you have to pass a qualifying exam every two years, and do not get any benefits. Rite Aid is a good example. they pay low, not benefit, and no overtime. Pharmacy techs just have to cover if on is off sick, as the company will not allow the overtime a worker would get if called in to cover.

Sure fast food workers do not get paid very well, but neither do many skilled workers. Worse yet we have the activist investors buying out companies and cutting staff to be able to pay themselves more dividends and bonuses.

Perhaps you missed his statement regarding protection for baseline needs?  Moreover, your approach suggests carte blanche powers (from and by whom?) to equalize outcome.  That sounds vastly more risky than a life of opportunity to all but the most entrenched bureaucrats or perhaps those who conceptually mean well, but are unconcerned with historical precedent for such an approach.

High Inequality and High Mobility = Very High Risk Lives

Well, Cowen is always happy to mislead for the libertarian/plutocratic cause, and he has to, as the truth gives no chance to his side in a democracy.

But this extreme inequality is fine if we have high mobility is so wrong, because high mobility is high chance to go up and high chance to go down. If it's just high chance to go up, that's just growth (which is decreased when you don't invest in the 99+% to give as much as possible to the 1%, or 0.1% or 0.01%).

High inequality with a high probability of plunging into the abyss because of high mobility? That's just a terribly risky life for you and your family, and risk decreases utility and welfare. Who wants to live in a world made that dangerous. And certainly the high mobility that the rich will allow is among the 99%, not among the 0.1% or 0.01%.

There may or may not be anything more, which is where faith or belief inevitably comes into it. But in the meantime, whether faith-inspired or not, our lives should be about improving ourselves in our interactions with others; about trying to raise our consciousness, no? And that's what makes this show so interesting to me. The characters struggle with change and struggle to change. In the end they don't handle either particularly well. But watching them deal with it is extremely interesting.
They've reached an understanding based on a more mature view of the way life is. But they always seemed to have a better relationship than, say, Betty and Sally.

The one thing Don has gotten better at, I would argue, is being a father. To Sally, if not the boys, but it's something. Or has Sally just gotten better at being his daughter and making it work for her?
You mean still palling around with a wolfish Roger wasn't enough?  (I don't mean that meanly; but I had the same thought as soon as we saw them with the floozies in the diner.)

Very thorough and spot on analysis.  Don still seems to be in a fever dream of sorts, or else he is having blackouts.  That opening scene where he takes the flask out was pretty chilling--and I suspect, a good indicator of where the final episodes might be going.
It is shiva, not a wake.

.
I think we are not supposed to disclose in Comments that the show will go beyond episode 39.

Some reader/commenters may have planned to tune into that episode looking for a big blowout series finale! Now it's SPOILED.

Ah, there you have it. There IS nothing MORE. There is just our own individual acceptance (or not) that we matter very little, yet a thoroughly self-aware determination to carry on nevertheless. This is what adulthood means. Some of the characters are growing up, and some are simply growing old. It's a very human story, universal in so many ways.

I have yet to see the episode, but this was such a delight to read. Every word I savoured before consuming the next.  Perhaps I'm a bit taken by your detailed insight and recall of the series, but I enjoyed your vivid animation of the episode especially the comparisons to early episodes. It's so rare to read such well-written and thoughtful articles online that I had to thank you for it.
All of the above and more. The paperback is yet another image that the writers push into our minds. It furthers and enriches the narrative. What masterful storytelling!

Just a reply to myself. I realized last night that Dos Passos died in 1970 which is the year of the episode. Although, he died in September which is later in the year than the April when Nixon made the speech.

Good analysis.
I think I need some help though on an item that was a clear plant or clue but there wasn't a clear or slam dunk connection revealed. The joke that Roger made and the closeup of the waitress carrying DosPassos' USA ( from my memory of the Signet paperback covers it was The 42nd Parallel or the first book of the trilogy), what was that about?
I discovered USA about the time of the episode in 1970 while in HS and have read and reread the trilogy many times. The 42nd Parallel primarily focuses on J. Ward Moorehouse who develops into a powerful public relations figure from humble beginnings in Wilmington, Del. at the turn of the 20th Century and has early jobs in advertising. There are a number of parallels between Draper and J. Ward (although not the drinking and sexual antics ). Are the writers revealing a model for the character, a homage to the book, or what?

.
Very interesting, IPLawyer!

So, Paige could run for President in or after 2004?

Personally, I love the show! I love that it's a giant step for womankind! I adore Lena Dunham, and she might as well be the first woman to walk on the moon with her brave and necessary real woman nude scenes. I wish I had gone to the schools she went to growing up, wished my daughters could have as well. Their schools, educators, and parents, and whomever else contributed to their lives certainly did a great job of building strong women with artistic passion, talent, drive, spunk, and tons of flare. How lucky are we to enjoy this progressive thinking entertainment? I love all the characters and the actors. I say keep on keeping on, I could happily watch whatever they come up with for the next decade. I too can't help wishing for an Adam Hannah revival, but I am more interested in seeing how these real women make it through. I have a daughter who like Marni tried to make it in the music business for many years in Portland, in and out of bands. She had her narssasitic times, but mostly, it's just a lot of insecurity, and a passion to keep doing what she loves. I have two daughters who lived similar lives full of relationship ups and downs, and in and then moving on of careers. It's not Sex in the City, where jobs fall into your lap with huge butt loads of money, not in the real world. That is the best part of the story. It's both down to earth and also somewhere up in the stratosphere.
Spot on.  Excellent summary and analysis of Mad Men.  Best piece I've read about this wonderful series aside from M. Weiner's notes.

This episode's existentialism was an apt follow-up to Bert's parting words to Don. The visual callbacks to his earlier relationships were well done -- like a lifetime flashing before the eyes of a dying man. Draper is still trying to escape the reaper through status and sex, but the shock of Rachel's death may have brought him up sharp. We shall see.

great premiere. i remember in an interview weiner mentioned that despite the show's different time period, the characters' day to day issues are consistent with the same problems we face today. they're consistent w ours because people are human and will always be imperfect despite the progression of time. so, yes, a decade has passed. but don's still don. make no mistake about it.
it's the last season, and for me at least, he is just as unlikeable.

i thought one of the themes of this episode was actually the tenuous nature of progress. when joan takes her frustrations out in a luxurious shopping trip only to be asked by the sales associate if she used to work there... you know she just wants to relish in her new power/wealth, but reality seems to bring her back down as if nothing's changed. or peggy, she is now powerful and in control again, but watching the scene of her albeit successful date, i can't help but think back to her trying to date in the earlier episodes. she is just as eager (... suggesting to go to paris on a first date? even she is embarrassed the next morning)
It's unnecessarily rude to start off a comment with "Um...."  You really should correct this.

Pretty shocking error, given that the word and an explanation is used as soon as Don opens the door to the apartment.   And it was particularly funny that after the explanation, Don says something along the lines of, 'I know, I've lived in New York for a long time.   I guess Mr. Hill has not.
Um, it's not a "wake" where Don talks to the sister. It's a shiva. You really should correct this.
Peggy is Don with a past, which either makes her healthier or more twitsted, I do not know.

I agree with you. This has been a fatal flaw in the final season of several shows recently.  They take too much time getting around to the conclusion (if there is to be one, instead of a gentle fade-out, which is possible, as MW seems wedded to the idea of the series just being a slice of life) and then have to rush to cram in all kinds of stuff, usually in a horrible montage overlayed with music.   Only Six Feet Under really did that well.

I sure hope the story line speeds up a bit. We get that Don is hopelessly lost, maybe doomed. Pete is whiny and greedy. Joan angry and unhappy. Roger quickly becoming a dirty old man.  Peggy becoming a female Don. The only people who are happy escape the twilight zone they are trapped in. I was hoping we might see these characters in the future say 1990 or so. I am afraid we will just see them wallow through 1970.
My previous response should have been edited.  The first sentence was wrong.  Sorry!!

What struck me the most was the comment from the waitress to him about how death caused people to run out and find meaning is something that I believe Don has been doing all along.  What if all there is in life is the monotonous acts we engage in everyday? The song throughout the episode eluded to the same thing.
Yes you are right about Wesley Taylor. He also played 'Bobby' on "Smash".
I thought Wesley Taylor played RD's nephew.
Oops, not a wake.  That was Don paying a shiva call.

In fact, Rachel's sister (was her sister, right? whoever greeted Don) explained (undoubtedly for the sake of non-Jewish viewers) the family was sitting Shiva, and that it is a week of mourning. In fact, if you look at the scene, you will see a big sheet in the background, probably draped over a mirror (tradition includes covering all the mirrors in the house). At least he brought food, also customary; though quite possibly it won't be eaten, if the household keeps strict kosher.
They actually SAY they are sitting shivah.
Doubt very much Rachel Katz had a wake. More than likely it was a shiva.

You know the other one that deserves happiness? Sally.

I know it's sentimental to say this, but I really hope that she and Don forged some new understanding of each other in the 1st half episodes. Acceptance is a difficult concept for a girl/young woman Sally's age but perhaps they can actually enjoy each other, maybe even love each other in a way they have both never experiences from a parent before.

I loved the episode because I love having MAD MEN.  Whether any of the characters learn or grow or evolve or not, I so love having them in my living room again.  It was truly gratifying to see Peggy have fun.  Real fun.  I will be very disappointed if she lets this fish of the hook in a dismissive and cruel way.  At least one character on this show deserves a happy ending as we go gently into that goodnight over the next seven weeks.  I would love it to be Peggy or Joan.  After all, the male characters---especially Don---don't really seem to be seeking lasting happiness, only momentary.  But Joan and Peggy deserve more than a new, expensive dress or one enjoyable date. They've each put up with so much crap, they deserve bliss.

Yes, the current campaign was for Wilkinson (Wilkinson Smooth); but the OP is correct that Don started out writing copy for a furrier.  I mentioned this in my comment as well.  Also, Don met Betty while she was modelling, I think for the furrier.
Di as in die.  But the characters are all hunting for meaning, love, happiness and striking out.  It's certainly not Diana for the goddess of chastity! :)

You think that's who Don thought she looked like?  She doesn't really look much like Rachel.  Both have dark hair, but Rachel's is longer.  Rachel has bigger eyes, is taller, ... I don't see much of a resemblance.

Thought it was interesting that the ad campaign the episode began with was for fur coats...that's how Don met Roger. He was working at Heller's, a fur coat shop, and Roger came in to buy a coat for Joan and saw one of Don's ads. Between that, the references to Rachel saying he missed his flight, Don hooking up w/the stewardess, trying to run away to Paris but not being able to find the passport...this episode seemed to be all about trying to get away from the past by running away from problems and finding escape impossible. Even the waitress who looked so familiar -- named Dawn (Don?) -- proved not to be a real escape, but a meaningless quickie in the alley. Will the season's theme be about finally facing the past to be free? Can't wait to find out!

Loved your analysis. What captivated me about this show was that there was no lesson to learn; it was just a tale, messy, involved, people figuring it out as they went along and being who they were; in short, for me, it showed life with all its twists and turns. There are not always lessons to be learnt, yet that does not take away from the richness of experiencing life. The lives of these men and women have been engrossing and entertaining to watch, a cultural phenomenon that will live on in the memories of  fans like me!
